speaker: Best-Edited Half-Hour Series for Television
text: Ron Volk  ## Nominated  EMMY
nextSpeaker: Outstanding Sound Mixing for a Comedy Series or Special

speaker: Outstanding Sound Mixing for a Comedy Series or Special
text: Thomas J. Huth, Andre Caporaso, Robert Douglass, Dana Mark McClure  * * *  ## Transcript {david langley}     **A VALENTINE FOR NILES**  _Scene 1 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  The apartment is set up for a romantic dinner.  Niles is on the phone, Eddie is sitting on the ottoman._

speaker: Niles
text: Francois.  It's Niles Crane.  You delivered some champagne earlier for Valentine's Day?  Well, you brought over the '88 and I asked for the '85.  Yes, my date will know the difference, she happens to be the president of my wine club. Thank you, thank you.  Yes, remember, I won't be at home. No, I'm not entertaining at the Shangri-La, my brother was kind enough to let me use his apartment.
prevSpeaker: Outstanding Sound Mixing for a Comedy Series or Special

speaker: Niles
text: Well, what could I do?  I threw a blanket over it.  All right. Now, hurry, please, this woman is very particular. [_He hangs up and looks at Eddie._] Lucky for you she loves dogs.  [_N.B. Throughout the rest of this scene, all of Niles's dialogue is mutters or mumbles as he deals with the situation._] _He starts a CD of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" on the stereo, then sits on the couch.  He examines a crease on his pant leg, then adjusts it.  He then uncrosses his legs and compares the creases. He stands up and fluffs his pants legs out, then sits again.  He looks at his watch, examines his crease again, then gets up.  He goes to the kitchen and brings back the ironing board and a cloth. He sets up the board and plugs the iron in.  He removes his shoes, then his trousers, turning his back nervously on Eddie to do so. Laying them on the board, he covers the crease with the cloth and begins pressing them.  After glancing at his watch, he begins pressing faster.  Reaching for the cuff, he notices a loose thread. He tries to pull it off, then bite it off, but is unsuccessful.  He rushes over to the desk and gets a pair of scissors from the drawer.  He starts to hurry back to the ironing board, but slows and carefully makes sure the scissors are pointing down.  As he trims the loose thread, Eddie jumps on a dining chair and starts nosing around a place setting.  Niles notices and starts to yell at him, but ends up cutting his finger.  He yelps, puts the finger in his mouth and then looks at it.  It is bleeding, and the sight of blood makes him woozy.  He recovers, but notices Eddie still licking around the plate.  He snaps his fingers at him, which aggravates the injury and makes him look at his finger again.  This time, he passes out and falls over the arm of the couch.  Eddie comes over and licks his face, waking him.  He glances at his finger, then holds it up away from his face.  Looking down, he notices a spot of blood he's left on the couch.  He dabs it with his handkerchief, but it isn't effective.  He wraps the handkerchief around his finger, and goes to the kitchen, returning with a cloth and a can of solvent.  He sits on the couch and tries to read the instructions, bringing a candle closer for more light.  Apparently reaching the part about open flames, he hurriedly pushes the candle away.  Opening the can, he soaks a bit onto the cloth and begins dabbing up the blood stain.  He stands up to check his work and is satisfied.  When he's reaching for the cap to the can, however, his handkerchief falls off, he sees his bloody finger and again faints over the arm of the couch.  This time, the open can of solvent begins spilling onto and soaking into the couch.  Eddie barks loudly, waking him again.  He gets up, holding his wounded finger above his head once more.  He picks up the handkerchief to put on his finger, then gets the can and caps it, all over his head as Eddie looks on.  He goes into the kitchen and -  Reset to: the kitchen where Niles puts the solvent away under the sink and throws the towel into it.  Standing there, he begins to smell something.  He quickly checks the pots on the stove and in the oven, but they are all right.  He looks about in confusion, then exits.  Reset to: the living room.  Niles stands around, obviously still smelling something wrong.  His gaze travels to the ironing board just in time to see that the iron, which he left face down, has set his pants on fire.  He rushes over and grabs the iron, setting it aside.  He then tries to pat the flames out, only spreading them.  He tries to bundle the pants up but, burning his fingers, throws them away from himself. This carries them onto the couch where they promptly ignite the soaked- in solvent in a burst of flames.  Eddie barks as Niles stares, frozen.  Finally, he breaks and runs to the hallway, returning with a fire extinguisher.  He runs in front of the couch and squeezes the handle.  Nothing happens, and he notices that the safety pin is still in place.  He pulls it free and squeezes again.  The force of the extinguisher is too much for him to control, and he spins wildly around, dousing all the furniture, the carpet, the table setting, Eddie and himself with foam as Eddie furiously barks at him.  He gets it under control just in time to point it at the couch as it runs out of pressure.  He throws the empty extinguisher on Martin's chair and races to the kitchen.  He comes back with and oven mitt and pot holder and carrying the pans from the stove.  He empties the dinner onto the fire, putting it out and raising a cloud of steam.  Choking on the smoke and fumes, Niles opens the front door.  Looking desperately at his watch, he begins fanning the door to try and clear some of the smoke.  He then starts fanning with his arms, swinging so wildly that the mitt, pot holder and handkerchief all fly into the hall.  He glances at his finger, sees the blood and faints in the doorway.  As the smoke alarm goes off, Eddie jumps on the couch and begins eating the remains of the food.  The Mozart piece reaches a crescendo and ends.  FADE OUT  End of Act 1  Act 2_  **A VALENTINE FOR FRASIER**  _Scene 1 - A Restaurant Fade in.  It is a fancy restaurant, couples at the tables, a violinist playing.  Frasier is seated alone at a table, glancing nervously at his watch.  He pulls out his cell phone and dials.  CUT TO: Roz's apartment as she puts on makeup.  Her phone rings and she answers.  During their dialogue, the scene cuts back and forth between Roz and Frasier:_

speaker: Roz
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, it's Frasier.  Look, I need your help.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I don't have much time, I'm on my way out.

speaker: Frasier
text: OK, just answer me this: How do you know if you're on a date?

speaker: Roz
text: Are you alone?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Roz
text: Then you're not on a date.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very funny.  Listen, I'm at a restaurant, waiting for Cassandra Stone - you know, our new publicity director? She asked me out for dinner, and well, I was very flattered. I mean, I think she's a terrific woman.  It's just I'm starting to wonder if this is a business dinner, or more of a romantic date.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, you're going out for dinner on Valentine's Day, sounds like a date to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, she didn't realize it was Valentine's Day until I reminded her.  She did say she wanted to go over a new ad campaign.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, come on, every time I see you two together, she's got her hands all over you.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's always got her hands all over everybody.  She's a big flirt.

speaker: Roz
text: That's true.  She even flirted with me the first time I met her 'til I took off my baseball cap and parka.  Why don't you just ask her if it's a date?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz, I can't do that, what if the answer is "No"?  For God's sake, it'll be awkward all through dinner.  Awkward at work.  Imagine how embarrassing it'll be if it gets around the station.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I guess you're just gonna have to play it by ear. Well, you'll know what she has in mind by the way she dresses, how she acts, how she treats you...

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, yeah, I guess you're right.

speaker: Roz
text: [_as the doorbell rings_] Oh, there's my date.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, who are you going out with tonight?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, Bob.  You know, the tax accountant.

speaker: Frasier
text: Isn't he the one who drones on so incessantly you call him "The Cricket"?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I call him "The Cricket" because he rubs his hands together really fast during sex.  Bye.

speaker: Frasier
text: Goodbye.

speaker: Frasier
text: Cassandra.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Sorry to keep you waiting.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's OK.  I was just starting to wonder if you'd changed your mind.

speaker: Cassandra
text: What, and pass up dinner with the sexiest man in radio?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well.  It's just our plans were so last-minute, I thought maybe I misunderstood.

speaker: Frasier
text: My, things have certainly been clarified, haven't they?

speaker: Cassandra
text: Will you excuse me for a second?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course.  _She heads to the coat check, Frasier begins motioning to the violinist._

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me.  Excuse me.  You see that woman over by the coat-check?

speaker: Violinist
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's my dinner companion for the evening and things have taken a turn towards the romantic.  I want to make her feel as special as possible. [_He gives the violinist some cash._]

speaker: Violinist
text: Then you should have offered to check her coat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, thank you very much!  All right, just play something romantic when she gets back.  _Cassandra comes back to the table, meeting Mario, the Maitre d', on the way._

speaker: Mario
text: Miss Cassandra, so nice to see you again.

speaker: Cassandra
text: You too, Mario.  And how's the sexiest Maitre d' in Seattle?  _She leans in and kisses him just like she did Frasier.  Mario seats her and Frasier sits as well._

speaker: Cassandra
text: Sorry again for keeping you waiting.  I got sucked in at this cocktail party.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you were at a cocktail party.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Some benefit thing.  It was very fancy.  Obviously, why else would I show up wearing this?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why else indeed.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Oh, they have the best wine list here.  Do you feel like sharing a bottle?

speaker: Frasier
text: If you like.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Good thing I took a cab here, I'm a real lightweight. Then again, I'm sure a gentleman like you wouldn't mind escorting me back to my room after dinner, will you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think that can be arranged.

speaker: Cassandra
text: I love the food here.

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you recommend?

speaker: Cassandra
text: I'll start with the anchovies and red peppers, and then the garlic chicken with scallions.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Are you in the mood for oysters?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, I'm not sure.  _FADE OUT on his confused look.  Scene 2 - Cassandra's Hotel Room. Fade in.  The door opens on Cassandra and Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, here we are.  Your hotel room.  Last stop.

speaker: Cassandra
text: [_after a pause_] Oh, come on in. [_They enter_] Oh, thank you so much for this coat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Oh, God, I can't believe we got caught in that rainstorm, I'm freezing!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, me too.

speaker: Cassandra
text: [_coming close to him and lowering her voice_] Oh, I know something we can do to warm up real fast.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, all we have to do is...

speaker: Cassandra
text: Have a brandy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!  Let's have a brandy!

speaker: Cassandra
text: The mini-bar's over there.  I'll be right out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh-huh.  _She goes to the bathroom.  Frasier pulls out his cell phone and dials._

speaker: Roz
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz.  It's Frasier.

speaker: Roz
text: Where are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm in Cassandra's hotel room.  She invited me up here after dinner.  I'm just not sure what it means.

speaker: Roz
text: What it means?  What it means is that even a blind pig finds an acorn once in a while.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm still getting a lot of conflicting signals here.  You see, maybe she just invited me up here to talk business.  I just wish I could get one clear, unambiguous sign.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Oh, I just had to get out of that dress.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, here's your brandy.

speaker: Cassandra
text: I'll just go dry my hair.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I'm back.

speaker: Roz
text: She ditched her dress and she's hitting the sauce.  What do you need, runway lights on the mattress?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, Roz it's not as clearcut as it seems.

speaker: Roz
text: Look, Frasier, she is way out on a limb here.  Do you know how rejected she's gonna feel if you don't make a move?  You're gonna blow it forever.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're right.  I'm going to take off my jacket.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  Go get 'em, cowboy.

speaker: Cassandra
text: [_calling out_] Frasier?  Are you making yourself comfortable?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Cassandra
text: If it's OK, I still have some questions about the ad campaign I'd like to ask you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's why I'm here.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Or if you prefer, we could just talk about it over breakfast tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Breakfast, you say?

speaker: Cassandra
text: I hope I wasn't being presumptuous.  We will be having breakfast tomorrow, won't we?

speaker: Frasier
text: Absolutely.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Great!  So who else wil be there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Where?

speaker: Cassandra
text: At the breakfast meeting.  The one for the sponsors here at the hotel, tomorrow.  You just said you were going, right?

speaker: Frasier
text: The meeting.  Of course.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Frasier, what are you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I, uh...

speaker: Cassandra
text: I thought you said you were going to make yourself comfortable.  Why don't you check the closet?  I'm sure you can find somthing to slip into.  I'm just going to take my lenses out.

speaker: Cassandra
text: [_again calling from the bathroom_] You know, I'm really glad I asked you to dinner.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_taking off his pants_] Gosh, so am I.

speaker: Cassandra
text: You may not believe this, but I almost chickened out at the last minute.  It just goes to show it's always better to take the risk.  I mean, so you say "No."  I'm an adult, what's a little embarrassment?

speaker: Frasier
text: I couldn't agree more.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Did you find the slippers?

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Cassandra
text: In the closet.

speaker: Cassandra
text: You stepped in that puddle after dinner, I thought you might want to get out of those wet shoes and socks.  It's up to you, I know some people feel funny about taking their shoes off in someone else's room.  My gosh, it's really starting to come down out there.  You know what I'm thinking?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_a pained look on his face_] No.  I truly don't.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Well, it doesn't make much sense for you to drive home in this weather, especially since you are coming back for breakfast anyway.  Why don't you just stay over tonight?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_unsure_] All right.  When you say "Stay over", you mean of course...?

speaker: Cassandra
text: [_coming out, now dressed in just a shirt_] Stay here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, here.  Right.  Splendid.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Oh, my God!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_jumping up_] What?  I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

speaker: Cassandra
text: I just can't believe it's so late.  What are you sorry for?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just for... keeping you up so late.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Oh, that's all right.  Aren't you coming to bed?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  Coming to bed.  Coming to... this bed.

speaker: Cassandra
text: Well, would you mind turning the lights out?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no, no, not at all.  _He turns out the light, and in the darkness can be heard slipping into bed._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Cassandra, I know this may sound like a silly question seeing as how we're... in bed together and... nearly naked, and... I've just been wondering: Is this a romantic date, or... a business thing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, it's Frasier!  _FADE OUT  End of Act 2  Act 3_  **A VALENTINE FOR DAPHNE AND MARTIN**  _Scene 1 - Another Resaurant, Russano's Fade in.  Again, it is a fancy restaurant with couples at the tables. Martin leads Daphne to a table._

speaker: Martin
text: You know, Daph, I'm really impressed with you.  A lot of people get all insecure if they don't have a date on Valentine's Day, but not you.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, heaven's no.  If you think about it, it's just a silly holiday they made up to sell more flowers and candy.

speaker: Martin
text: Right.  Well, you take a look at the menu and I'll check your coat.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, no need for that.  So, what looks good to you?

speaker: Martin
text: [_grabbing her coat_] The coat-check girl.  Gimme your coat.

speaker: Maitre d'
text: Happy Valentine's Day, welcome to Russano's.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.

speaker: Maitre d'
text: The waiter will be by to take your drink order when your husband gets back. [_leaves_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he's not my husband.  I don't have a... husband.  _She trails off as she notices all the happy couples around her. Martin comes back._

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting_] Wow, I wish there was somethin' else I could check. Besides my blood pressure.  Well, I know what I'm in the mood for, a nice big steak.  How 'bout you?

speaker: Martin
text: What happened?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_sobbing_] Well, look around you.  Nothing but couples in love.  It's never gonna be me.  I'm just going to end up a dried-up old maid in a quilted bathrobe with a smelly deaf cat on my lap!

speaker: Martin
text: But I thought you said you were OK with that.

speaker: Daphne
text: What?!

speaker: Martin
text: All right, Daph.  Come on, now, come on, now, don't get upset, here, have a drink of water or somethin'.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'm sorry about this.

speaker: Martin
text: That's OK.

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't know what came over me.  I haven't cried like that since, well... [_crying again_] New Year's Eve.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez, come on, Daph.  You're, uh, you know, you're going to find someone.

speaker: Daphne
text: You think so?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, sure.  Yeah, you're... you have a lot of very great qualities.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.  I'm so sorry about this.  I know it makes you uncomfortable to talk about personal things.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, well, that's all right.  So, you ready to order?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah.

speaker: Daphne
text: What kind of qualities?

speaker: Martin
text: Well... you know, you're smart, and nice-looking, and fun to be with.  So you gonna go with the soup or salad?

speaker: Daphne
text: You really think I'm nice-looking?

speaker: Martin
text: [_flustered_] Well, sure, yeah.  Where's that guy with the bread?

speaker: Daphne
text: That is so sweet of you.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, don't mention it.  Let's just have a nice happy evening.

speaker: Daphne
text: Of course.  I'm fine now. [_after another short pause_] Nice- looking how?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, never mind.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, no it's all right.  Well, you know, you're pretty and, uh... tall, and uh... take good care of your hair, you know... You're attractive, what do you want from me?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm sorry, but I don't here this sort of thing very much lately.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you're just in a slump, that's all.  You ask me, you're a great catch.

speaker: Waiter
text: It's not my place to say so, Miss, but I think your father's right.  You're a very attractive woman.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, how about that?  That's a nice little ego boost.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Daphne
text: I feel so silly all of a sudden.  Getting upset out of nowhere like that.  Well, I feel better now.  Ready to share a nice big steak?

speaker: Martin
text: [_grumpy_] Yeah, fine, whatever.

speaker: Daphne
text: What's wrong with you?

speaker: Martin
text: Why did he assume I was your father?  I mean, a lot of guys my age go out with women like you.  What's he tryin' to say? That I could never attract someone young and pretty?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, thank you, Mr. Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: Does this all have to be about you?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, for heaven's sakes.  You're a very attractive man with lots of wonderful qualities.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah, I know.  All right, let's order.

speaker: Martin
text: Like what?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, come on now.  You're very charming, and you have a good sense of humor.  And you've got lovely eyes. [_he laughs modestly_] But most of all, you're good company.  I enjoy living with you.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, thank you, Daphne.  I like living with you, too.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.

speaker: Daphne
text: So why do you like living with me?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for God's sake, can't we just agree to cut this out?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, all right, all right.  You're wonderful, I'm wonderful. You know it's funny when I think about the two of us.  I mean, sure, we have our little fights, but for the most part we get along so well together.  And when I think about how I enjoy looking after you, and how you always seem to miss me when I've been gone for too long, well it's sort of like you're my...

speaker: Martin
text: [_smiling_] What?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, it might sound funny to say this...

speaker: Martin
text: No, come on, that's all right, you can say it.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right.  Well, it's sort of like you're my pet.

speaker: Martin
text: What?!

speaker: Daphne
text: In a good sense.  Like you and Eddie.

speaker: Martin
text: What the hell you talkin' about?  You callin' me a dog now?!

speaker: Daphne
text: It's an analogy, for God's sake... _The two begin loudly bickering as everyone stares at them, Martin throwing in some comment about Eddie eating better than he does on her cooking, Daphne coming back that he could stand to lose some weight, etc. etc. etc.  Fade out._

speaker: Credits
text: Martin is standing in the entrance to the dining room, when the coat-check girl brings his and Daphne's coats.  He brings some money out of his pocket and tips her, then digs around again and tips her a little extra.  She touches his shoulder and gives him her sexiest smile.  Martin takes the coats to their table, where Daphne is having a drink with the waiter who called her attractive.  She shoos Martin away, and he merrily goes back to chatting up the coat-check girl.    * * *  ## Guest Appearances    **Special Guest Star** VIRGINIA MADSEN as Cassandra Stone  **Guest Starring** PETER WALDMAN as Violinist LAWRENCE LOWE as Waiter ARMANDO MOLINA as Mario,
